orbital.label: Earth's orbital changes
orbital.title: Is it orbital changes?
orbital.sub: No. Shifts in Earth's orbit led to past changes in climate, but this has had little influence since 1880.

solar.label: Solar temperature
solar.title: Is it the sun?
solar.sub: No. The amount of energy the Sun radiates does vary in cycles, but not enough to cause the observed warming.

volcanic.label: Volcanic activity
volcanic.title: Is it volcanoes?
volcanic.sub: No. Volcanic eruptions have a short-term cooling effect.

land_use.label: Land use
land_use.title: Is it change in land cover?
land_use.sub: No. When trees are cleared for crops and livestock, the exposed land surface reflects incoming sunlight. This has a slight cooling effect.

aerosols.label: Aerosols
aerosols.title: Is aerosol pollution?
aerosols.sub: No. Some chemicals in airborne pollutants reflect solar energy instead of absorbing itâ€”but have other negative effects, like smog and acid rain.

ghgs.label: Greenhouse gases
ghgs.title: Is it greenhouse gases?
ghgs.sub: Yes. The rise in heat-trapping greenhouse gases is the only factor that matches observed warming since 1880.

all.label: All factors
all.title: All factors combined
all.sub: Greenhouse gases account for warming the planet, while deforestation and aerosol pollution have cooled it slightly. This line represents all human and natural factors together.
